details: Elemmírë was a Vanyarin Elf of Valinor of unknown gender.

name: Elemmakil
details: Elemmakil was an Elf of Gondolin.

name: Elenwë
details: Elenwë was a Vanyarin elf, the wife of Turgon and the mother of Idril, to whom she passed on the golden hair of her kindred.

name: Elatan
details: Elatan was a nobleman who lived in the city of Andúnië during the early centuries of Númenor. He wedded Silmariën, the daughter and eldest child of Tar-Elendil, the fourth King of Númenor.

name: Eldarion
details: Eldarion (Quenya: IPA; "Son of the Eldar") was the only son of Aragorn II Elessar and Arwen Undómiel, King and Queen of the Reunited Kingdoms of Gondor and Arnor in Middle-earth.

name: Eldalótë
details: Eldalótë was the wife of Angrod, the second son of Finarfin. She was also grandmother of Gil-galad and Finduilas.

name: Eldacar (King of Gondor)
details: Eldacar, born as "Vinitharya", was the twenty-first King of Gondor and the son of Valacar and the northwoman Vidumavi, he was born during the time his father was acting as ambassador to Rhovanion.

name: Eldacar (King of Arnor)
details: Eldacar was the fourth King of Arnor.

name: Elboron
details: Elboron was the son of Faramir and Éowyn.

name: Eilinel
details: Eilinel was an Edain woman of the First Age.

name: Eglantine (Banks) Took
details: Eglantine Took, née Banks was a Hobbit of the Shire. She was a member of the Banks family and was the mother of Peregrin Took.

name: Egalmoth (elf)
details: Egalmoth was an Ñoldorin Elf-lord of Gondolin in the First Age.

name: Egalmoth
details: Egalmoth was the eighteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor.[2]

name: Ecthelion of the Fountain
details: Ecthelion, or Ecthelion of the Fountain, was a mighty lord of Gondolin during the First Age of Middle-earth, and one of its greatest heroes.

name: Ecthelion I
details: Ecthelion I was the seventeenth Ruling Steward of Gondor.[2]

name: Ebor
details: Ebor was the son of Meleth and Agathora, and brother to Manthor, his lord, and Hunthor.

name: Edrahil
details: Edrahil was an Elf of Nargothrond.

name: Ecthelion II
details: Ecthelion II was the twenty-fifth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Dúnhere
details: Dúnhere was the chieftain of the folk of Harrowdale, and a valiant captain who fought in the First Battle of the Fords of Isen and the Battle of the Pelennor Fields. He is also the nephew of Erkenbrand.

name: Dírhael
details: Dírhael was the grandfather of Aragorn II Elessar and father of Gilraen.

name: Dís
details: Dís was a Dwarf woman of Durin's Folk.

name: Déorwine
details: Déorwine was a Man of Rohan of the late Third Age.

name: Déor
details: Déor (r. TA 2699 - TA 2718) was the seventh King of Rohan.

name: Durin's Bane
details: "Durin's Bane" refers to the particular Balrog of Morgoth that had fled following the War of Wrath to dwell deep within the depths of the Dwarven kingdom of Moria.

name: Déagol
details: Déagol, also known as Nahald, was a Stoor-hobbit of the Gladden Fields. Déagol was the cousin and best friend of Sméagol until his discovery of the Ring.

name: Dáin II Ironfoot
details: Dáin II Ironfoot (or simply King Dáin) was the son of Náin and the grandson of Grór, the youngest son of Dáin I of Durin's folk, and was lord of the Dwarves of the Iron Hills in Wilderland.[1] He was a Dwarven King of Durin's Folk, the fifth King under the Mountain, and the Lord of the Iron Hills during the War of the Ring in Middle-earth in the late Third Age.

name: Dwalin
details: Dwalin was one of the Dwarves who traveled with Bilbo and Gandalf on the quest to regain the Lonely Mountain from Smaug. He was the brother of Balin and the youngest son of Fundin.

name: Dáin I
details: Dáin I was a Dwarf and a King of Durin's Folk during the Third Age. He was the son of Náin II and had a younger brother named Borin. He had three sons: Thrór, Frór, and Grór.

name: Dírhavel
details: Dírhavel was a minstrel of the Edain during the later First Age, and was only known for one composed lay in all his life, but it became the greatest and the most remembered of all the lays made by Men.

name: Dwarves named "Durin"
details: Durin was the name of many Dwarves in the First, Second, and Third Ages, starting with Durin the Deathless, after whom the Line was named.

name: Durin VII
details: Durin VII was the descendant of Thorin III Stonehelm and possibly the last of the line of Durin's Folk.[1]

name: Duinhir
details: Duinhir was the leader of the Men from the uplands of Morthond, the great Blackroot Vale.

name: Duilin
details: Duilin was the son of Duinhir and the brother of Derufin.

name: Draugluin
details: Draugluin was the first werewolf to be bred by Morgoth during the First Age of Middle-earth.

name: Dorlas
details: Dorlas was a Edain Man of the House of Haleth from Brethil who went with Túrin and Hunthor to slay the dragon Glaurung, but he ran in fear from the beast and was later killed by Brandir. He was the father of Avranc, a later enemy of Túrin's father.

name: Dori
details: Dori was a Dwarf of Durin's Folk, who along with his brothers Nori and Ori travelled with Bilbo Baggins and Thorin Oakenshield as a member of Thorin's Company on the Quest for Erebor, to reclaim the Lonely Mountain from the Dragon Smaug.

name: Rosa (Baggins) Took
details: Rosa Took, née Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Reginard Took
details: Reginard Took was a Hobbit of the Shire of the Took clan.

name: Dodinas Brandybuck
details: Dodinas Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

culture: Lives in a small, poor town of Men. Does not have enough money to put supper on the table, not to buy proper clothes for the weather.
race: Half elven mother, which was kept a secret to her until after her mother was killed and she was forced to run, right into the secrets of her bloodline.
details: Hello, my name is Káera Everwood, and welcome to my very boring wiki page. LOTR has always been my favorite movie, as well as The Hobbit, ever since I was a young child.

name: Pervinca Took
details: Pervinca Took was a sister of Pippin.

Sigismond Took

details: Pearl Took was a Hobbit of the Shire, and a sister of Pippin.

name: Paladin Took II
details: Paladin Took II was the thirty-first Thain of the Shire, and the father of the famous hobbit Peregrin Took.

name: Lalia (Clayhanger) Took
details: Lalia (Clayhanger) Took was a Hobbit of the Shire and the wife of the Thain Fortinbras Took II.

name: Pimpernel Took
details: Pimpernel Took was the second daughter of Paladin Took and sister to Pippin Took. She was a guest at Bilbo's farewell party.

name: Hildigrim Took
details: Hildigrim Took was the great-grandfather of Peregrin Took and Meriadoc Brandybuck, as well as one of the many uncles of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Gerontius Took
details: Gerontius Took, more commonly known as The Old Took, was a Hobbit of the Shire and the twenty-sixth Thain of the Shire. He was best known for being the third oldest Hobbit in Middle-earth's history, living to the ripe old age of 130 years. Only Bilbo and Gollum, whose lifetimes were prolonged by the powers of the Ring, lived longer.

name: Hildibrand Took
details: Hildibrand Took was a Hobbit of the Shire and one of the many uncles of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Ferumbras III Took
details: Ferumbras III, while not otherwise particularly famous, was the thirtieth Thain at the time of the Farewell party of Bilbo Baggins at the beginning of The Lord of the Rings. He was the son of Fortinbras Took II (TA 2878 – TA 2980, a cousin of Bilbo) and Lalia (Clayhanger) Took. He never married because no one wanted Lalia for a mother-in-law.

name: Isembard Took
details: Isembard Took was one of the many uncles of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Hildifons Took
details: Hildifons Took was one of the many uncles of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Ferdibrand Took
details: Ferdibrand Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Flambard Took
details: Flambard Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Ferdinand Took
details: Ferdinand Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Bandobras Took
details: Bandobras Took, more commonly known as Bullroarer, was a Hobbit of the Shire and the hero of the Battle of Greenfields.

name: Adelard Took
details: Adelard Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Adamanta (Chubb) Took
details: Adamanta Took, née Chubb was a Hobbit of the Shire.

details: Isengrim Took II was a Hobbit of the Shire and the twenty-second Thain of the Shire.

name: Isumbras Took III
details: Isumbras Took III was the twenty-third Thain of the Shire.

name: Adalgrim Took
details: Adalgrim Took was a Hobbit of the Shire, and the grandfather of Meriadoc Brandybuck and Peregrin Took.

name: Faramir Took I
details: Faramir Took was a Hobbit of the Shire and the son of Peregrin Took and Diamond of Long Cleeve, and the thirty-third Thain of the Shire.

name: Everard Took
details: Everard Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Isumbras Took I
details: Isumbras Took I was a Hobbit of the Shire and the thirteenth Thain of the Shire, the first of the Took line.[1]

name: Tom, Bert, and William
details: Tom, Bert, and William ("Bill") Huggins were three Stone trolls that Bilbo Baggins encountered in the Trollshaws, in Eriador, while with Thorin and Company on their quest to regain the Lonely Mountain (Erebor). Like most of their kind outside of Mordor, they were vagabonds who robbed, stole, and killed for what they needed or wanted. Their age is unknown. They were destroyed by sunlight which turned them to stone with the aid of Gandalf's trickery.

name: J.R.R. Tolkien
details: In addition to The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, Tolkien's published fiction includes The Silmarillion and other posthumously published books about what he called a legendarium, a fictional mythology of the remote past of Earth, called Arda, and Middle-earth (from middangeard, the lands inhabitable by Men) in particular. Most of these works were compiled from Tolkien's notes by his son Christopher Tolkien. The enduring popularity and influence of Tolkien's works have established him as the "father of the modern high fantasy genre". Tolkien's other published fiction includes adaptations of stories originally told to his children and not directly related to the legendarium.

name: Théoden
Tindómiel
details: Tindómiel was the second child and only daughter of Elros Tar-Minyatur, Half-elven and the first King of Númenor.

name: Tilion
details: Tilion (Quenya; IPA: [ˈtili.on] - "The Horned")[1] was a Maia and the guardian of the Moon.

name: Théodwyn
Fortinbras Took II
details: Fortinbras Took II was a Hobbit of the Shire and the twenty-ninth Thain of the Shire.

name: Thrór
details: Thrór was a King of Durin's Folk, the son of Dáin I, the grandson of Náin II, the father of Thráin II, the brother of Frór, and Grór, the grandfather of Thorin II Oakenshield, Frerin, and Dís, and the great-grandfather of Fíli and Kíli.

name: Thráin I
details: Thráin I, also known as Thráin the Old, was the son of Náin I and King of Durin's Folk and the first King under the Mountain.

name: Thorondor
details: Thorondor (Sindarin; IPA: "Eagle Lord") was the King of the Eagles of Middle-earth during the First Age.

name: Thorondir
details: Thorondir was the twenty-second Ruling Steward of Gondor.[2]

name: Thranduil
details: Thranduil, son of Oropher, was an Elven king who ruled over the Woodland Realm in the Second and Third Ages. Though inherently cautious, he eventually committed his kingdom to fighting against Sauron in the War of the Ring. He was the father of the Elven prince of Mirkwood, Legolas, who was a member of the Fellowship of the Ring.

name: Thorin II Oakenshield
details: Thorin II, also called the Oakenshield, King under the Mountain or the Mountain King,[1] was the son of Thráin II, the older brother of Frerin and Dís, the grandson of King Thrór and the uncle of Fíli and Kíli. Thorin was best known for his deeds as leader of a company that infiltrated the lost Kingdom under the Mountain to take it back from Smaug and for leading an alliance of Men, Dwarves, and Elves in the Battle of the Five Armies.

name: Thorin I
details: Thorin I was the son of Thráin I, whom he succeeded as King under the Mountain and King of Durin's Folk.

name: Thorin III Stonehelm
details: Thorin III Stonehelm was the son and heir of Dáin II Ironfoot of Durin's folk, who was king of the Dwarves of Erebor and the Iron Hills in Wilderland.

name: Thengel
details: Thengel was the sixteenth King of Rohan.

name: Thranduil's Second Elk
details: Thranduil's Second Elk is the elk that Thranduil uses in The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies. Unlike Thranduil's first elk, he has a creme as well as a dark brown colouration.

name: Thuringwethil
details: Thuringwethil was a Vampire servant of Sauron in his fortress of Tol-in-Gaurhoth (the former Tol Sirion), during her time serving Morgoth during the First Age.

name: Tim
details: Tim (perhaps Tim Bombadil) is the 'nuncle' of Tom Bombadil, mentioned in the poem The Stone Troll.

name: Thráin II

name: The King of the Dead
details: The King of the Dead, originally "King of the Mountains", was the King of the Dead Men of the Mountains in Dwimorberg, and before that had been a living Man. His spirit resided along with that of his kin in the Paths of the Dead.

name: Dina Diggle
details: Dina Diggle was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Thingol
details: Elu Thingol was an Elf of the Teleri during the First Age. His brother was Olwë, who became the Lord of Alqualondë, Lord of Tol Eressëa, and High King of the Teleri of Aman, both of whom may have had a second brother called Elmo. He was a good friend of Finwë, the first High King of the Ñoldor during the times before the elves reached Aman.

name: Dior
details: Dior, also called Dior Eluchîl, was the son of the renowned Man Beren the One-handed of the House of Bëor (First House of the Edain) and the legendary Elven-princess Lúthien of Doriath. He thereafter became the King of Doriath as he was heir to the throne of King Thingol of Doriath and also became the High King of the Sindar. Dior the Fair was one of the Half-elven for his father was of the race of Men and his mother was Elven.

details: Diamond "of Long Cleeve" Took was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Damrod

name: Denethor (First Age)
details: Denethor was the son of the Nandor Elf leader Lenwë (or Dan), who lived during the Years of the Trees.

name: Daeron
details: Daeron (also spelled "Dairon") was a Sindarin elf of Doriath and King Thingol's loremaster and minstrel. Because of his love for Lúthien, he was jealous of Beren One-hand, and was a key figure in the betrayal of their love to Thingol.[1]

name: Carl Cotton
details: Carl had three older brothers: Tolman (Tom) Jr., Wilcome (Jolly), and Bowman (Nick) along with his dad fought in the Battle of Bywater. Being the youngest, he was exempt from the battle.

name: Rosie Cotton
details: Rosie Cotton, nicknamed Rose, was a Hobbit of the Shire. She was the wife of Samwise Gamgee, the renowned companion of Frodo Baggins during his quest to destroy the One Ring. She was the mother of Frodo Gardner, Elanor, Rose, Merry, Pippin, Goldilocks, Hamfast, Daisy, Primrose, Bilbo, Ruby, Robin, and Tolman (Tom).

name: Curufin
details: Curufin, also called Curufin the Crafty,[3] was a Ñoldorin prince and the fifth of the seven Sons of Fëanor and Nerdanel. Curufin is the father of Celebrimbor, master Jewel-smith of Eregion who would later forge the three Elvish Rings of Power.

name: Tarciryan
details: Tarciryan was the son of Siriondil and the younger brother of Tarannon Falastur.

name: Tarannon Falastur
details: Tarannon was the twelfth King of Gondor.

name: Tar-Telperiën
details: Tar-Telperiën was the tenth ruler and second Ruling Queen of Númenor. She succeeded her father, King Tar-Súrion (who was King because his two elder sisters had no interest in ruling).

name: Tarcil
details: Tarcil was the sixth King of Arnor.

name: Tar-Telemmaitë
details: Tar-Telemmaitë was the fifteenth King of Númenor.[1]

name: Tar-Míriel
details: Tar-Míriel was the daughter of King Tar-Palantir, and the last rightful heir of Númenor.

name: Targon
details: Targon was a Man of Gondor.

name: Tar-Palantir
details: Tar-Palantir was the twenty-fourth King of Númenor.

name: Tar-Súrion
details: Tar-Súrion was the ninth King of Númenor, succeeding his father Tar-Anárion.[1]

name: Tar-Ciryatan
details: Tar-Ciryatan or Ar-Balkumagân in Adûnaic, was the twelfth King of Númenor. His rule marked the first coming of the shadow upon the Númenóreans and their rulers, the speaking out openly against the Valar and the Ban, colonialism, and dominion abroad.

name: Tar-Calmacil
details: Tar-Calmacil was the eighteenth ruler of Númenor. He succeeded his father, Tar-Alcarin, as king. His name means "Bright Sword", which he took in recognition of the territorial victories he had in Middle-earth as a renowned captain of Númenor.[1]

name: Tar-Minastir
details: Tar-Minastir was the eleventh King of Númenor. He was King during the War of the Elves and Sauron in the mid-Second Age, he helped defeat Sauron by sending a relief force to the aid of Gil-galad who was under siege in Middle-earth.[2]

name: Tar-Atanamir
details: Tar-Atanamir also known as Atanamir the Great was the thirteenth King of Númenor.[1]. He is best known for being the first to openly question the Ban of the Valar.[2]

name: Tar-Anárion
details: Tar-Anárion was the eighth King of Númenor.

name: Tar-Ardamin
details: Tar-Ardamin (Q, pron. [taˈrardamin]) or Ar-Abattârik is sometimes listed in the list of rulers of Númenor but is sometimes omitted. He was the son of King Tar-Calmacil, and if he is counted as one of the rulers, then he is the nineteenth in the line of kings.

name: Tar-Ancalimon
details: Tar-Ancalimon was the fourteenth King of Númenor. He succeeded his father, Tar-Atanamir.

name: Tar-Ancalimë
details: Tar-Ancalimë was the seventh ruler of Númenor and the first Ruling Queen .

name: Tar-Amandil
details: Tar-Amandil was the third King of Númenor.

name: Tar-Aldarion
details: Tar-Aldarion was the sixth King of Númenor, and succeeded his father, Tar-Meneldur. Tar-Aldarion was married to Erendis, a Númenórean woman, who was not quite of the same status as Aldarion himself, and therefore had a shorter life-span. Aldarion's love for the sea ultimately caused a rift between the couple and they separated in SA 882.[1] The tale of their marriage and estrangement survived the Downfall of Númenor as "Aldarion and Erendis, The Mariner's Wife".

name: Soronto
details: Soronto was a Númenorean nobleman of the royal lineage of Númenor or the House of Elros, the grandson of Tar-Meneldur and son of Ailinel, a sister of Tar-Aldarion.[1] He lived during the later years of the first millennium of the Second Age. His father was Orchaldor, a descendant of the House of Hador.

name: Tar-Alcarin
details: Tar-Alcarin was the seventeenth King of Númenor.[1]

name: Morwen Steelsheen
details: Morwen Steelsheen was a beautiful dark-haired woman who lived in the region of Gondor until she moved to Rohan where she married Thengel, son of Fengel.

name: Tanta (Hornblower) Baggins
details: Tanta Hornblower was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Story tellers
details: Characters in J.R.R. Tolkien's works who tell large, significant accounts of the history of Middle-earth.

name: Squint-eyed Southerner
details: The Southerner (aka the squint-eyed Southerner) was an old man from the hills of Dunland, an outlaw with possible Orc ancestry.

name: Smaug
details: Smaug was a fire drake of the Third Age, considered to be the last "great" dragon to exist in Middle-earth. He was drawn towards the enormous wealth amassed by the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain during the reign of King Thror, and laid waste to the neighboring city of Dale and captured the Lonely Mountain, driving the surviving Dwarves into exile.

name: Snaga (Grishnákh's band)
details: Snaga was the name of an Orc in Grishnakh's band sent to assist Saruman's Uruk-hai in February of TA 3019.

name: Snaga
details: Snaga was the name of an Orc in the Tower of Cirith Ungol.

name: Robin Smallburrow
details: Robin Smallburrow, nicknamed Cock Robin, was a longer-standing Shirriffs within the Shire at the time of the end of the Third Age and during Sharkey's attacks on the Shire.

name: Siriondil
details: Siriondil was the eleventh King of Gondor.

name: Tar-Vanimeldë
details: Tar-Vanimeldë was the sixteenth ruler of Númenor and third and last ruling Queen of Númenor.[1]

name: Silmariën
details: Silmariën was a noble Woman of Númenór known for being the sire of the Lords of Andúnië and the heir of heirlooms of the Dúnedain.

name: Scatha
details: Scatha was one of the greatest of the Long-worms that infested the Grey Mountains in the north of Middle-earth.

name: Sauron
details: Sauron (or Þauron (Thauron); Quenya; IPA: [ˈsaʊron] or Vanyarin; IPA: [ˈθaʊron] - "The Abhorred"), the eponymous Lord of the Rings, was a fallen Maia, the creator of the One Ring, and the most trusted lieutenant of his master Melkor (Morgoth, the first Dark Lord). After Melkor's defeat in the First Age, Sauron became the second Dark Lord and strove to conquer Arda by creating the Rings of Power. In the Second Age, he was defeated in the War of the Last Alliance by the last line of defense: Elves and Men under kings Gil-galad and Elendil.

name: Celebrimbor
details: Celebrimbor was a Ñoldorin prince, and the last in the line of the House of Fëanor, who lived in Middle-earth. He was a ruler of Eregion in the Second Age, and a master smith. He is remembered primarily for his creation of the three greatest Elven Rings of Power: Vilya, Narya, and Nenya.

name: Seers
details: All items (4)

name: Castamir the Usurper
details: Castamir the Usurper usurped the throne of Gondor from Eldacar, ruling from TA 1437 to 1447 of the Third Age, until he was violently deposed at the Battle of Erui.

name: Seers
details: Seers were certain people of Arda who possessed an either practiced, gifted, or innate ability to predict major events; a magic ability even Wizards did not particularly have. This classification excludes characters who had the gift of foresight but are never referred to as "seers" or "prophets", such as Elrond.

name: Sheila Chandra
details: Ten years later, she had burning mouth syndrome, and has no longer been able to sing.

name: Celeborn
details: Celeborn was the Lord of Lothlórien, and the husband of Galadriel, Lady of the Golden Wood. He was said to be one of the wisest Elves in Middle-earth at the end of the Third Age.
I am a Fangirl of the following: The Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, The Mortal Instruments, The Infernal Devices, Harry Potter, The Hunger Games, and a lot more.

name: Tar-Meneldur
details: Tar-Meneldur was the fifth King of Númenor. His two older sisters were Silmariën and Isilmë. During his time the Númenóreans began to return to Middle-earth, and great fleets of ships were built to explore all the lands east of Númenor.

name: Caranthir
details: Caranthir, also known as Caranthir the Dark,[4] was the fourth son of Fëanor and the harshest and the quickest to anger of his seven brothers.[5]

name: Carcharoth
details: Carcharoth, also known as the Red Maw, lived in the First Age of the Sun, and was the greatest werewolf who ever lived. He was of the line of Draugluin.

name: Caliondo
details: Caliondo was the son of Eärendur, the second son of Tar-Amandil, the third King of Númenor.

name: Carl Cotton (Cottar's son)
details: Carl was a Hobbit of the Shire and the son of Cottar, the founder of the Cotton family.

name: Calimmacil
details: Calimmacil was a nobleman of Gondor during the mid-Third Age. He was the son of Arciryas and the grandfather of Eärnil II and was also the father of Siriondil.

name: Bór
details: Bór was a leader of Easterling Men of the First Age.

name: Calimehtar
details: Calimehtar was the thirtieth King of Gondor.

name: Barliman Butterbur
details: Barliman Butterbur was a Man of Bree and the owner of The Prancing Pony in the town of Bree.

name: Bëor
details: Bëor, also known as Bëor the Old, was the chieftain of the first house of the Edain to cross the Blue Mountains into Beleriand during the First Age.

name: Moro Burrows
details: Moro Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Mosco Burrows
details: Mosco Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Milo Burrows
details: Milo Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Asphodel (Brandybuck) Burrows
details: Asphodel Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Bucca of the Marish
details: Bucca of the Marish was a Hobbit of the Shire and the first Thain of the Shire. He originated from the Marish region of the Shire.

name: Myrtle Burrows
details: Myrtle Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Minto Burrows
details: Minto Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Bregolas
details: Bregolas was one of the Edain of the House of Bëor. He was also the third Lord of Ladros.

name: Brodda
details: Brodda was a lord of the Easterlings. He usurped the lordship of Dor-lómin after Húrin was captured, and Morwen had since left the area. He married Aerin sometime after that. A little while before the coming of 499, the First Age, Brodda was involved in a battle that took place inside the hall of his own grandious home. He was ultimately slain by Túrin in his rage.

name: Brego
details: Brego was the second King of Rohan.

name: Rorimac Brandybuck
details: He was married to Menegilda Goold and had two children with her: Saradoc "Scattergold" and Merimac. He was a brother of Primula (Brandybuck) Baggins, mother of Frodo, and was the grandfather of Meriadoc Brandybuck . He lived from 1302-1408 Shire Reckoning.[1]

name: Primula (Brandybuck) Baggins
details: Primula Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire, the mother of Frodo Baggins, who was one of the many bearers of the Ring, and the cousin of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Bregor
details: Bregor was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor.

name: Sapphira (Brockhouse) Boffin
details: Sapphira Boffin, formerly Sapphira Brockhouse was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Salvia (Brandybuck) Bolger
details: Salvia (Brandybuck) Bolger was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Seredic Brandybuck
details: Seredic Brandybuck was a Hobbit of Buckland.

name: Mirabella (Took) Brandybuck
details: Mirabella Took was the eleventh child and youngest daughter of Gerontius "The Old" Took and his wife Adamanta Chubb. Mirabella had ten older siblings: Isengrim III, Hildigard, Isumbras IV, Hildigrim, Isembold, Hildifons, Isembard, Hildibrand, Belladonna, and Donnamira; and one younger sibling: Isengar.

name: Merimac Brandybuck
details: Merimac Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Mentha Brandybuck
details: Mentha Brandybuck was a young and beautiful Hobbit who lived in the country of Buckland, which bordered east from the Shire during the Third Age.

name: Orgulas Brandybuck
details: Orgulas Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Gorbadoc Brandybuck
details: Gorbadoc was married to Mirabella Took and was the father of seven children, including Primula. He was the grandfather of Frodo Baggins and great-grandfather of Meriadoc Brandybuck. His parents were Marmadoc Brandybuck and Adaldrida Bolger. Born in TA 2860 (SR 1260), he was noted by the Gaffer for "keeping a mighty generous table." Gorbadoc was the Master of the Hall (Brandy Hall) in Buckland. He died in TA 2963 (SR 1363).[1]

name: Ilberic Brandybuck
details: Ilberic Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Melilot Brandybuck
details: Melilot Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Estella (Bolger) Brandybuck
details: Estella (Bolger) Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Esmeralda Brandybuck
details: Esmeralda Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Hilda Brandybuck
details: Hilda Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Marmadoc Brandybuck
details: Marmadoc was born in TA 2817 (SR 1217) and was the son of Madoc Brandybuck and his wife Hanna Goldworthy. He lived in Buckland in Brandy Hall. He married Adaldrida Bolger and had two children, the later well known Gorbadoc and Orgulas Brandybuck. On the death of his father in TA 2877, he became Master of Buckland until his death in TA 2910 (SR 1310).[1]

name: Celandine Brandybuck
details: Celandine Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire, a second cousin of Meriadoc Brandybuck.

name: Berilac Brandybuck
details: Berilac Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Amaranth Brandybuck
details: Amaranth Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Adaldrida (Bolger) Brandybuck
details: Adaldrida Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Brandir
details: Brandir, known as Brandir the Lame, was a Lord of the Haladin in the First Age who dwelt in the Forest of Brethil which was west of Doriath in the settlement of Ephel Brandir, in Middle-earth.

name: Borthand
details: Borthand was the Easterling Man, son of Bór, possibly the youngest of his three sons.

name: Doderic Brandybuck
details: Doderic Brandybuck was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Brand
details: Brand was a prince, who, upon his father's death, became King of Dale and fought during the War of the Ring. Brand was the son of Bain and the grandson of Bard the Bowman, who slew the dragon Smaug. Brand became King of Dale in TA 3007. He maintained good relations with the Dwarves of the Lonely Mountain and his realm extended as far south as the River Running and as far east as the Redwater.

name: Borondir
details: Borondir also known as Borondir Udalraph was a Man of Gondor.

name: Boron
details: Boron was an Edain of the House of Bëor.

name: Boromir (Steward)
details: Boromir was the eleventh Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Boromir (House of Bëor)
details: Boromir was the elder son of Boron, the third chieftain of the folk of Bëor, and he was the great-grandson of Bëor the Old. He also had a younger brother named Belegor which not much is mentioned about him. Boromir became the fourth Chieftain of the House of Bëor after the death of his father. When the Elven Kings decided to grant lands to the chieftains of the Edain, Boromir was granted the land of Ladros in Dorthonion as a fief under the Elven-lords Angrod and Aegnor, the younger sons of Finarfin (the Noldorin king in Aman) and the brothers of King Finrod of Nargothrond. He thus became the first Lord of Ladros.

name: Bruno Bracegirdle
details: Bruno Bracegirdle was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Blanco Bracegirdle
details: Blanco Bracegirdle was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Primrose Bracegirdle
details: Primrose Bracegirdle was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Boromir
Lavender (Grubb) Boffin
details: Lavender (Grubb) Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Borlas
details: Borlas was a Man of Gondor in the Fourth Age, and a key figure in J.R.R. Tolkien's short-lived story The New Shadow. He had two children, an unnamed daughter and a son Berelach, a friend of Saelon.[1]

name: Ivy (Goodenough) Boffin
details: Ivy Goodenough was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Hugo Boffin
details: Hugo Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Jago Boffin
details: Jago Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Gruffo Boffin
details: Gruffo Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Madoc Brandybuck
details: Madoc Brandybuck was a Hobbit of Buckland and the third Master of Buckland.

name: Griffo Boffin
details: Griffo Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Gerda (Boffin) Bolger
details: Gerda Bolger was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Folco Boffin
details: Folco Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Druda Burrows Boffin
details: Druda Burrows Boffin, formerly Druda Burrows, was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Daisy (Baggins) Boffin
details: Daisy (Baggins) Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Buffo Boffin
details: Buffo Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Briffo Boffin
details: Briffo Boffin (b. TA 2770 (SR 1170) ? was a Hobbit of the Shire and of Bree.

name: Bosco Boffin
details: Bosco Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Basso Boffin
details: Basso Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Blanco
details: Blanco was a Fallohide Hobbit adventurer and one of the two recognized founders of the Shire.

name: Donnamira (Took) Boffin
details: Donnamira Boffin was a Hobbit of the Shire and an aunt of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Bodruith
details: Bodruith was an Indrafang (Longbeard) Dwarf, of the kindred of the Nauglith. He was the Lord of Belegost and was one of the wicked dwarves who appeared in the The Book of Lost Tales. He was killed by Naugladur when starting a war between the two clans of Dwarves.

name: Bob
details: Bob was a Hobbit of Bree.

name: Bladorthin
details: Bladorthin was a King of Men in the Northeast sometime during the late Third Age. His realm was probably close in proximity to Lonely Mountain, because in The Hobbit Thorin and Balin remember and wonder if Bladorthin's order is still intact:

name: User:Bitterhand/Workbench1
details: Gimli, son of Glóin, was a well-respected dwarf warrior in Middle-earth during the Great Years. He was a member of the Fellowship of the Ring, and was the only one of the dwarves to readily fight alongside elves in the war against Sauron at the end of the Third Age. After the defeat of Sauron, he was given lordship of the Glittering Caves at Helm's Deep.

name: Bilbo Baggins
details: Bilbo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire, the main protagonist of The Hobbit and a secondary character in The Lord of the Rings.

name: Bifur
details: Bifur was a Dwarf of the late-Third Age. He is best known for being a companion to Bilbo Baggins and Thorin Oakenshield on the quest to regain the Lonely Mountain, along with his cousins Bofur and Bombur.

name: Bergil
details: Bergil was the older son of Beregond of Gondor. A boy of ten at the time of the War of the Ring, he accompanied Peregrin Took when he first arrived in the city of Minas Tirith. Bergil had an uncle named Iorlas, who was the same age as Pippin. It is not certain whether Iorlas was the brother of Beregond or of Bergil's mother, although Iorlas does not follow the alliterative pattern evident in males known to be related to Beregond (Bergil, Borlas).

name: Beren (Steward)
details: Beren was the nineteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Beren (Belemir's son)
details: Beren (son of Belemir) was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor.

name: Berúthiel
details: Berúthiel was a Queen of Gondor in the Third Age before the reign of the Stewards.[1]

name: Beren
details: Beren, also called Beren Erchamion, was a man of Middle-earth, and a hero whose romance with the Elf Lúthien was one of the great stories of the Elder Days that were told for many ages after he lived.

name: Berelach
details: Berelach was the only son of Borlas and had an unnamed older sister.

name: Beregond (Captain)
details: Beregond, son of Baranor, was the first Captain of the White Company, the guard of Faramir, Prince of Ithilien, and previously, a Guard of the Citadel in Minas Tirith. He is best known for rescuing Faramir from the madness of Denethor during the Siege of Gondor.

name: Beregond
details: Beregond was the twentieth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Bereg
details: Bereg was a man of the House of Bëor.

name: Belen
details: Belen was an Edain of the House of Bëor and Bëor's second son.

name: Belemir
details: Belemir was an Edain of the House of Bëor during the First Age.

name: Belegund
details: Belegund was a Edain and a Man of Dorthonion and one of Barahir's Outlaws.

name: Belegorn
details: Belegorn was the fourth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Beleg of Arnor
details: Beleg was the second King of Arthedain.

name: Beleg
details: Beleg, also known as Beleg Cúthalion or Beleg Strongbow, dubbed for his good bowmanship, was a Sindarin elf who served in the army of King Elu Thingol of Doriath as Chief Marchwarden[2][3] - and was a predominant companion of Túrin Turambar.

name: Belecthor II
details: Belecthor II was the twenty-first Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Belecthor I
details: Belecthor I was the fifteenth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Beldis
details: Beldis was an Edain woman of the House of Bëor.

name: Beldir
details: Beldir was a man of the House of Bëor.

name: Beechbone
details: Beechbone was one of the younger Ents who lived in Fangorn Forest, and was said to be a very tall and handsome Ent.

name: Bard II
details: Bard II was the fourth King of Dale. He was the youngest of the previous kings to rule over Dale at the age of 34 after his father's death in battle.

name: Baranor (Gondor)
details: Baranor was a Man of Gondor. Some time during his life he married and had a son named Beregond. It is unknown if he had other children.

name: Baranor
details: Baranor was a man of the House of Bëor.

name: Baran
details: Baran was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor, who lived during the First Age.

name: Barahir (Steward)
details: Barahir was the eighth Ruling Steward of Gondor.

name: Barahir (Fourth Age)
details: Barahir lived sometime during the second century of the Fourth Age possibly during the threat of the New Shadow in Gondor. He was also the author of The Tale of Aragorn and Arwen which can be found in Appendix A of The Lord of the Rings.[1]

name: Barahir
details: Barahir was an Edain Man of Dorthonion during the First Age, heir to the House of Bëor, youngest son and last child of Bregor, the fifth chieftain of the People of Bëor, and husband of Emeldir who was also of the House of Bëor through the line of Belen, the youngest son of Bëor. Barahir was most famous for being the father of the renowned Beren Erchamion. He was also the fourth Lord of Ladros and the seventh and probably last Chieftain of the Bëorians after his deceased elder brother Bregolas.[2][3] Besides his elder brother, Barahir had three elder sisters: Bregil, Hirwen, and Gilwen.[4]

name: Baragund
details: Baragund was an Edain of the House of Bëor.

name: Willie Banks
details: Willie Banks was a Hobbit of Bree.

name: Baldor
details: Baldor also known as Baldor the Hapless, was the oldest son of Brego, 2nd Lord of the Mark, and brother of Aldor, 3rd Lord of the Mark.

name: Balcmeg
details: Balcmeg was one of the Orcs killed in the Fall of Gondolin by Tuor, according to The Book of Lost Tales.

name: Bain
details: Bain was a Man of Dale and the second king of the renewed Kingdom of Dale.

name: Ruby (Bolger) Baggins
details: Ruby Bolger (b. TA 2864 (SR 1264) - ?) was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Porto Baggins
details: Porto Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Ponto Baggins II
details: Ponto Baggins II was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Ponto Baggins
details: Ponto Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Balin
details: Balin was a Dwarf leader, the son of Fundin, and elder brother of Dwalin. He was one of the thirteen Dwarves who accompanied Thorin II Oakenshield on the quest to regain the Lonely Mountain.

name: Polo Baggins
details: Polo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Peony (Baggins) Burrows
details: Peony Burrows was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Pansy Baggins
details: Pansy Baggins (b. TA 2812 (SR 1212) - ?) was the daughter of Balbo Baggins and Berylla Boffin, and the great-aunt of Bilbo Baggins.[1]

name: Mungo Baggins
details: Mungo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire, the grandfather of Bilbo and the great-grandfather of Frodo.

name: Mimosa (Bunce) Baggins
details: Mimosa (Bunce) Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Longo Baggins
details: Longo Baggins was the third child of Mungo and Laura Baggins and the uncle of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Laura (Grubb) Baggins
details: Laura Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Largo Baggins
details: Largo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the great-grandfather of Frodo Baggins.

name: Fosco Baggins
details: Fosco Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the grandfather of Frodo Baggins.

name: Dudo Baggins
details: Dudo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Drogo Baggins
details: Drogo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the father of Frodo Baggins, who was one of the many bearers of the One Ring.

name: Chica (Chubb) Baggins
details: Chica (Chubb) Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the wife of Bingo Baggins, mother of Falco Chubb-Baggins and aunt of Bilbo Baggins.

name: Bungo Baggins
details: Bungo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the father of Bilbo.

name: Bingo Baggins
details: Bingo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Berylla (Boffin) Baggins
details: Berylla (Boffin) Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the wife of Balbo Baggins, the first recorded member of the Baggins family.

name: Belladonna (Took) Baggins
details: Belladonna (Took) Baggins was the mother of Bilbo Baggins and was from a very large, wealthy family with many siblings.

name: Balbo Baggins
details: Balbo Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire and the first recorded member of the Baggins family.

name: Angelica Baggins
details: Angelica Baggins was a Hobbit of the Shire.

name: Azaghâl
details: Azaghâl was the King of the Broadbeam Dwarves, one of the seven Dwarf clans, and Lord of the Dwarven realm of Belegost in the Blue Mountains during the First Age.

name: Axantur
details: Axantur was a nobleman of Númenor.

name: Aulendil (Vardamir's son)
details: Aulendil was the third child and the second son of the short-reigning king, Vardamir Nólimon.

name: Azog
details: Azog was an orc of the Third Age who commanded the tribes of Moria from TA 2790 [citation needed] until his death in TA 2799. He was responsible for the death of King Thrór and for King Thráin's madness.

name: Aulë
details: Aulë (Quenya; IPA: [ˈaʊle] - "Invention") was an Ainur, one of the Aratar and a Valar, who was responsible for fashioning and crafting the substances of which Arda, the world, was composed. He was also called Mahal (Khuzdul; IPA: "Maker"), Oli (Sindarin; IPA: "Dream") or Návatar and delights in the nature of substances and in works of skill, but not concerned with possession or mastery. Besides the shaping of Arda, Aulë's greatest works were the Two Lamps of the Valar, the vessels of the Sun and Moon, and the Dwarves, whom he created out of impatience for the Children of Ilúvatar. He also created Angainor (the chain of Melkor).

name: Arveleg II
details: Arveleg II was the son of King Araphor of Arthedain, and was named for his great-grandfather Argeleb I.

name: Atanatar II
details: Atanatar II was the sixteenth King of Gondor.

name: Atanatar I
details: Atanatar I was the tenth King of Gondor.

name: Atanalcar
details: Atanalcar was the youngest child and third son of Elros Tar-Minyatur, Half-elven and first King of Númenor.

name: Arveleg I
details: Arveleg I was the eighth King of Arthedain.

name: Asgon
details: Asgon was a man of Dor-lómin.

name: Arvegil
details: Arvegil was born in TA 1553. During his father's reign, Arvegil saw events that would shape the history of Middle-earth, including the foundation of the Shire. He was eighty-three years old (no great age for one of the Dúnedain) when the Great Plague came out of the south and ravaged Eriador, but the seat of the Kings at Fornost in the north was little affected.

name: Arvedui
details: Arvedui was the last King of Arthedain.

name: Arthad
details: Arthad was an Edain Man of the House of Bëor.

name: Artamir
details: Artamir was the eldest son of King Ondoher of Gondor. He, his father, and his younger brother were killed in battle with the Wainriders.[1]

name: Arminas
details: Arminas was a Ñoldor Elf of the First Age.

name: Arien
details: Arien (Quenya; IPA: [ˈari.en] or [ˈarijen] - "Maiden Of Sunlight") was a Maia and the Guardian of the Sun.

name: Argonui
details: Argonui was the thirteenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Argon
details: Argon was the fourth child and the youngest son of Fingolfin, the High King of the Ñoldor in Beleriand. He was one of the mighty Prince of the Noldor in Tirion, Valinor. Furthermore, Argon grew up in Valinor, until later, the Noldor went into exile for Middle-earth where he journeyed with his father Fingolfin and all of his siblings as well.

name: Argeleb II
details: Argeleb II was the tenth King of Arthedain. He is best remembered as being the one responsible for creating the Shire for the Hobbits.

name: Argeleb I
details: Argeleb I was the seventh King of Arthedain.

name: Aredhel
details: Aredhel, also known as Aredhel Ar-Feiniel,[2] the "White Lady of the Ñoldor", was the only daughter and third child of the Noldorin High-prince Fingolfin and his wife Anairë. Aredhel was the sister of Fingon, Turgon and Argon, and the mother of Maeglin.

name: Ardamir (son of Axantur)
details: Ardamir was a Man of Númenór.

name: Arciryas
details: Arciryas was a nobleman of Gondor.

name: Aravorn
details: Aravorn was the ninth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Aravir
details: Aravir was the fourth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Araval
details: Araval was the thirteenth king of Arthedain.[1]

name: Arathorn II
details: Arathorn II was the fifteenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain and father of the future Heir of Isildur, Aragorn II Elessar.

name: Arathorn I
details: Arathorn I was the twelfth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Aratan
details: Aratan was the second son of Isildur.

name: Arassuil
details: Arassuil was the eleventh Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Araphor
details: Araphor was the ninth King of Arthedain.

name: Araphant
details: Araphant was a Dúnedain of the North and the fourteenth King of Arthedain.

name: Aranwë
details: Aranwë was an Elf of Gondolin and the father of Voronwë.[1] His son stated that he was from the House of Fingolfin, suggesting that Aranwë might have been a noble elf in Gondolin.[2]

name: Aranuir
details: Aranuir was the third Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Arantar
details: Arantar was the fifth King of Arnor.

name: Aranarth
details: Aranarth was the first of the Chieftains of the Dúnedain, and would have been King of Arnor at the death of his father Arvedui, the last King of Arnor, had the North Kingdom not fallen. He also was chieftain for longer than any would be after him, ruling for 131 years.

name: Arahael
details: Arahael was the first of Isildur's Heirs to be born after the destruction of the North-kingdom. His father Aranarth therefore gave him over to Elrond while he dwelt in the wild, to be fostered in Rivendell, and this became the custom of the Chieftains of the North.

name: Arahad II
details: Arahad II was the tenth Chieftain of the Dúnedain.

name: Angrim
details: Angrim was the father of Gorlim, an unhappy member of Barahir's Outlaws.

name: Angelimir
details: Angelimir was the twentieth Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Angelimar
details: Angelimar was the twentieth prince of Dol Amroth, he was also the grandfather of Imrahil.

name: Angbor
details: Angbor was a Man of Gondor and the Lord of Lamedon at the end of the Third Age and beginning of the Fourth Age.

name: Angamaitë
details: Angamaitë was the great-grandson of Castamir. Along with Sangahyando, he became an important figure amongst the Haradrim and the Corsairs of Umbar.[1]

name: Andvír
details: Andvir was named as the son of Androg. He was one of the only man to escape from Amon Rûdh after the massacre of Turin's Outlaws, after Mîm's betrayal as depicted in The Silmarillion and The Children of Húrin.

name: Andróg
details: Andróg (IPA: [ˈandrɔːg]) was a Adan of the First Age in the band of outlaws that included Turin Turambar.[1] He was the father of Andvír.

name: Andreth
details: Andreth was an Edain of the House of Bëor. She was the second child and only daughter of Boromir and the sister of Bregor her elder brother and Beril her younger brother.

name: Ancalagon
details: Ancalagon, also known as Ancalagon the Black, was the greatest of all winged dragons. He was bred by Morgoth during the First Age, and was the largest dragon to have ever existed in Middle-earth. His appearance in history was restricted to the War of Wrath.

name: Anborn
details: Anborn was a Man of Gondor, a scout for the Rangers of Ithilien, and was Faramir's deputy.

name: Anardil
details: Anardil was the sixth King of Gondor.

name: Anairë
details: Anairë was an Elf of Valinor and the wife of Fingolfin.

name: Amrothos
details: Amrothos was the third son and the second child of Imrahil, the twenty-second Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Amroth
details: Amroth was an Elven king of Lothlórien.

name: Amrod
details: Amrod was the youngest son of Fëanor, along with his twin brother Amras. Of Fëanor's twin-sons, Amrod was the eldest.

name: Amnon
details: Amnon was a seer of Beleriand who in the First Age predicted the Fall of Gondolin by Morgoth's army.[1]

name: Amlaith
details: Amlaith, also known as Amlaith of Fornost,[1] was the first King of Arthedain.

name: Amlach
details: Amlach was the son of Imlach and the grandson of Marach[1], the leader of the third host of men to enter Beleriand, and an ancestor of Hador Lorindol. Originally, he did not trust the elves, and was the leader of dissension among the Men of Estolad. Later on, he repented and entered into the service of Maedhros.

name: Amdír
details: Amdír, also known as Malgalad[1], was an Elf of Doriath, the father of Amroth and King of Lothlórien.

name: Amarië
details: Amarië was a Vanyar Elf of Valinor in Aman.

name: Alphros
details: Alphros was the twenty-fourth Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Amandil
details: Amandil was the leader of the Faithful in Númenor, and came to be the eighteenth and last Lord of Andúnie. His life as Lord of Andúnie and as one of the Faithful sired the High Kings of Gondor and Arnor who preserved their ways through the Dúnedain of Middle-earth on up to Aragorn II Elessar. Elendil the Tall was his son.

name: Almiel
details: Almiel was the third child of Tar-Meneldur and younger sister of Ailinel and Tar-Aldarion.

name: Almarian
details: Almarian was a royal Númenórean woman and Queen of Númenor during the early Second Age.

name: Algund
details: Algund was Edain of the First Age and a member of the Gaurwaith.

name: Aldor
details: Aldor was the third King of Rohan, and the realm's longest reigning king.

name: Aldamir
details: Aldamir was the twenty-third King of Gondor (Castamir being counted the twenty-second).

name: Alatar
details: Alatar (Quenya; IPA: [ˈalatar] - "After-Comer"), also called Morinehtar (Quenya; [moriˈneçtar]) was a Maia and an immortal Istar wizard. He travelled to Middle-earth in the Second Age with Rómestámo (Pallando), and they became the Ithryn Luin, or "Blue Wizards". They travelled to the east of Arda, to countries in far eastern Middle-earth such as Rhûn and Khand, where they were sent to stir up rebellions against those serving Sauron. In this, they were successful, and they later returned to Middle-earth in the Third Age and travelled East and South once again, but they never returned to the West after their journey with Saruman. It is possible that they became the founders of secret and magical cults, but their ultimate fate remains unknown.

name: Ailinel
details: Ailinel was the second daughter of Tar-Meneldur and Almarian and the mother of Soronto.

name: Aghan
details: Aghan was a dark-skinned man of the Drúedain tribes. He had a friend called Barach, who lived on the borders of Forest of Brethil, two miles away from the nearest village. Aghan took to watching their house when orcs started raiding nearby.When his brother was ill, he made a statue to watch the house. When a group of orcs stared burning Barach's house, a mysterious Drug killed the orcs and put out the fires, but was burned by the flames. Aghan suffered from blisters at the same time. The mysterious Drug turned out to be the statue.

name: Aerandir
details: Aerandir was a faithful friend of Eärendil, and one of the three mariners that accompanied him on his voyages on the high seas west of Middle-earth.

name: Aglahad
details: Aglahad was the nineteenth Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Agathor
details: Agathor was an Edain of Brethil during the First Age.

name: Aerin
details: Aerin was an Edain woman of Dor-lómin.

name: Aegnor
details: Aegnor was a Ñoldorin Elf, the third son of Finarfin, elder brother of Galadriel, younger brother of Finrod Felagund and Angrod and lord of the Ñoldor of Dorthonion in the First Age.

name: Adrahil II
details: Adrahil II was the twenty-first Prince of Dol Amroth.

name: Adrahil I
details: Adrahil I was a Prince of Gondor who lived around TA 1944 in the land of Belfalas.
